p.s: The author tries to convince the readers of her opinion by structuring the text well.
At first she states facts, which are always very convincing (l. 1).
In the second paragraph Rahman talks about the bad situation in Brick Lane.
In Brick Lane drug abuse and crime are on the rise (l. 8) and by showing these bad conditions Zia tries to convince others to learn English so they don't have to live like this.
In the next paragraph Zia explains how she learned speaking English.
She shows that it is important to learn the language and gives others hope because she could do it so others can too.
At the end the author talks about the consequences and what one can do to help.

She thinks there is much to be gained in getting us all to speak English (l. 23) and as her last sentence this is very convincing because she promises that people will have less problems to integrate.
The author often mentions her parents (ll. 11-14).
By using this repititionrepetition she tries to underline that parents and generally the family plays a great part in learning a language.
Moreover one mostly listens to their parents so when she repeats them one sees that her parents wanted Zia to learn English so it has to be something one wants to achieve and what is good for kids.
With a metaphor (ll. 18-19) Rahman shows that it is important to do something on your own and that one cannot always depend on others.
If someone is holding you up(l. 19) all the time you don't learn to stand on your own feet (l. 19).
By this she means that if one always uses translations and is constantly [been] holding up (l. 19), one does not learn something and can notcannot learn to stand on [their] own feet (l. 18).
This underlines her position and that translating everything and not learning the language does not help.
In addition she uses personal pronouns like we (l. 3, 18) and us (l. 23).
By using these personal pronouns Zia shows that we together can change something and that this only works when we stick together.
The author mostly uses them in apealsappeals, which is convincing and makes others want to help beausebecause Rahman directly speaks to them.
Moreover the author uses a lot of negative words.
She uses drug abuse and crime (l. 9).
The Bangladeshi community sits at the bottom of educational achievement (l. 7) which shows that they live in bad conditions.
The author wants the readers to pity them and have empathy.
And when one has empathy one is more likely to help because they can put themselves in the position of others.
As they don't have choice and have to chose between extremists (l. 9) and the gangs on the streets (l. 10).
They don't have a hopeful future.
